stories.text:
My client has been charged for stopped EC2 instances (Ireland).

I am the one who assured him he would not have any computing cost (while the volume costs will still run, of course): I am migrating his instances out of AWS, one by one: it takes time, and I left all migrated instances as 'stopped', until the migration will be completed.

I've been pushing myself to migrate (so to stop) as many instances as possible to have a reduced monthly AWS bill, but my client realized nothing changed.

This official doc is pretty clear https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/Stop_Start.html but I also see in https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/Stop_Start.html a comment stating "I just got a reply from AWS customer support explaining a stopped instance in the same region could cause it be treated as running and hence charged": this user have been refunded, so I guess we will contact support and ask the same.

* Did any of you hit something similar?

Since my client had several EC2 in stopped state in the past years, how the hell are we going to be able to check the amount of the overcharge?
stories.title: AWS charged my client for stopped EC2 Instances

stories.text:
I am..

- 36yo

- most probably not depressed

- live in a 1st world country

- privileged to have a job that pays well

- expecting my first child after years of trying

..and deeply believe the future will be truly bleak. Even if we somehow manage to not find ourselves in a nuclear holocaust, there is no escape from climate change.

I really want to be optimistic, both for me and the people around me, but it's hard to see how or why I could start being an optimist.

Reading the stoics didn't have a significant effect; it felt more like a coping mechanism than a way forward. Moving to an industry that tries to build a future - not a better future, just a future - is quite challenging without a meaningful background in hard sciences. "Think globally, act locally" is a dogma I've been following since forever but it feels insufficient when it comes to some of the great challenges we are going to face soon.

Help me and others like me see the world with different eyes.
stories.title: Ask HN: How can I start thinking optimistically?

stories.text: I'd like to find out where and how I spent time precisely, is there some software that would monitor myself precisely? How much time in which window and tab and VSCode etc. is spent? I'm on Ubuntu, I'd be willing to pay for it.
